Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Interviewers and Their Effects from a Total Survey Error Perspective

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for an international conference on "Interviewers and Their Effects from a Total Survey Error Perspective." The conference will be held in February 2019 at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. The conference will focus on the study of interviewers as a source of survey error and the implications of research on this topic for survey practice. It will bring together up to 50 scholars from the US and other countries. The conference will produce results important to survey methodology and related social science fields and will develop a research agenda on interviewer effects, including best practices for studying and training interviewers. It will further pedagogical goals by clearly delineating study design and estimation approaches for the study of interviewer effects, and it will foster the entrance of junior scholars, graduate students, and new researchers to this important area. By bringing together established scholars, students, and practitioners from academia, government, and industry, this conference will permit immediate translation of findings into survey practice, will build research infrastructure, and will improve the quality of survey data collected by interviewers. Conference presentations will be widely disseminated. They will be made available in a publicly accessible archive, published in an edited volume from a scientific press, and developed into a short course for professional associations.

Researchers will come to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln during Spring 2019 to participate in a three-day interdisciplinary conference. The conference will include a mix of research presentations and discussion. The goal of the conference is to provide a forum for academic, government, and industry researchers and practitioners to discuss methods, practical insights, and research findings on interviewers. The major themes of the conference will be synthesizing and expanding knowledge about the impact of interviewers on multiple error sources, evaluating and disseminating study design and estimation approaches for studying interviewers, and integrating evidence from research and practice to produce an agenda for future studies of interviewers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Interviewers and Their Effects from a Total Survey Error Perspective 2.5-day workshop brought together an international group of leading academic, government, and industry researchers and practitioners for presentation of new research and intense discussion around the topic of interviewer effects on survey data. The goal of the workshop was to provide a forum for academic, government, and industry researchers and practitioners to discuss methods, practical insights, and research findings on interviewers. The workshop took place from February 26-28, 2019 on the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) campus, with senior scholars, students, early-career researchers, and survey operations professionals as participants. The workshop identified many areas for research on recruiting, training, and monitoring interviewers; how interviewers operate in different modes; virtual or avatar-based interviewers; success of interviewers in survey recruitment; variation in how questions are asked and answered across interviewers; and statistical analysis and estimation of the effects of interviewers on survey data. Graduate students from UNL were actively integrated into the planning and execution of the workshop as well as the creation of an edited volume containing papers from the workshop; students from the co-organizing committee institutions were also an integral part of the workshop’s success. The edited volume, Interviewer Effects from a Total Survey Error Perspective, published by CRC Press in May 2020, contains the conference proceedings. The volume includes 23 chapters, with an overview chapter from the conference organizing committee setting out a research agenda on interviewers and interviewer effects.

 


Last Modified: 07/01/2020
Modified by: Kristen Olson
